titleStmt.title: Information-centric mobile ad hoc networks and content routing: A survey

analytic.title: Information-centric mobile ad hoc networks and content routing: A survey

biblStruct.note: Received date: 29 February 2016 Revised date: 13 April 2016 Accepted date: 16 April 2016 Preprint submitted to Ad Hoc Networks

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: As the future Internet architecture, information centric networking(ICN) can also offer superior architectural support for mobile ad hoc networking. Therefore, information-centric mobile ad hoc networks(ICMANET), a new cross-cutting research area, is gradually forming. First of all, we introduce the current advances in ICN and analyze its development trends, and then interpret the formation of ICMANET and sketch an overview of it. Subsequently, we define a concept model for content routing and categorize the content routing into proactive, reactive and opportunistic, and then detail the representative schemes. Moreover, the existing issues are summarized. The goal of the work is to provide the references and guidelines for readers approaching study on the new area.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: With booming web applications and ubiquitous wireless access technologies, as well as widespread smart mobile terminals, users can share the user-generated content and popular content with the others in various forms, such as social networks and peered networks, etc. Internet, thus, is evolving from a original communication system to a content distribution platform. However, TCP/IP protocol suite applied by the current Internet requires IP address to identify and locate a host, and then maintain the end-to-end connection to realize reliable data transmission. The host-centric networking(HCN), consequently, fails to match with content-centric applications.

In order to fundamentally address the mismatch, academia proposed various architectures for future Internet, such as the DONA [1], CCN/NDN [2], NetInf [3] and PURSUIT [4], etc., which are collectively referred to as ICN [5]. The philosophy is to transform Internet networking from the host-centric to the content-centric one through naming, routing, caching and securing content. As a matter of fact, ICN is not only suitable for the future Internet but also for the ad hoc networking.

In the ad hoc wireless environment, there are some physical features, such as signal interference, multipath fading, shadowing effect and so forth. Besides, the frequent movement of nodes will cause dynamic change of topology and intermittent connection between nodes. Due to these features, it is difficult to directly apply TCP/IP to ad hoc networking. As a clean-slate approach, however, CCN/NDN using receiver-driven model [6] can enable two communicating parties to interact asynchronously without establishing and maintaining an end-to-end connection, and meanwhile the location-independent naming can eliminate the requirements of reassigning the host identifier(such as IP address) to the moving nodes. In addition, with in-network caching, each node is able to exploit full potentials of the broadcast nature of wireless channel [7] to listen and subsequently cache content, which lowers redundant requests and decreasing content retrieval latency. More generally, all these merits are consistent with the requirements of ad hoc networking.

div.head: A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T
div.p: The relevant literatures adopting the principles of ICN to ad hoc networking, consequently, have emerged recently. Beyond this, Conti et al. [8] prospectively indicates the current challenges in the sphere of ad hoc and particularly encourages to further explore the applicability of ICN for ad hoc networking. IRTF ICNRG also selects VANETs and DTN as the baseline scenarios of ICN [9]. Accordingly, a new cross-subjects research area is gradually forming, namely information-centric mobile ad hoc networks.

Unfortunately, even though Amadeo et al. [10] reviewed the state-of-the-art of information-centric wireless networking, Bouk et al. [11] focused specifically on ICN paradigm for VANETs, Amadeo et al. [12] discussed the potential of the ICN as a networking solution for connected vehicles and Yaqub et al. [13] identified a number of research challenges caused by the Interest packet forwarding issue in vehicular ICN, so far, there is a lack of the comprehensive study on ICMANET. To the best of our knowledge, the survey focusing on the formation or content routing of ICMANET is still deficient, and this is the first time that ICMANET has been introduced as the new cross-cutting area and content routing has been elaborated.

div.head: A C C E P T E D M
div.p: A N U S C R I P T

div.head: Current advances in ICN
div.p: In this section, we will demonstrate the current advances in ICN through the latest relevant projects, and subsequently analyze its development trends.

div.head: Latest projects
div.p: The projects related to ICN can be divided into two development stages, which are illustrated in form of time axis [5], as shown in Figure 2. During the first stage, a significant number of projects were related to architecture, such as the DONA, CCN/NDN, MobilityFirst [14], PSIRP/PURSUIT, 4WARD/SAIL, COMET [15], CONVERGENCE [16] and CONNECT [17], etc. In 2013, the National Science Foundation of United States continued to finance NDN and MobilityFirst through the Future Internet Architectures-Next Phase(FIA-NP) program, which has ICN step into the second stage. Xylomenos et al. [5] have provided detailed descriptions about the projects at the first stage, so they will not be repeated here. Moreover, we will attach importance to introduce the projects at the second stage in the paper.

div.head: CBMEN Phase2
div.p: Figure 2: The projects related to ICN NDN-NP still follows the idea of CCN but abandons CCNx prototype [18] originally developed by PARC. And it develops a brand-new NDN prototype, including the core component NFD [19], application class libraries and development tools so as to improve the overall performance of NDN. Except further study on issues of the protocol in term of naming, routing, caching and security, it will also deploy and test the prototype in the real scenarios, such as smart healthcare, cyber physical systems, as well as daily mobile multimedia applications.

MobilityFirst-NP, the successor of MobilityFirst project which proposed a clean-slate mobility-centric homonymous architecture, on one hand, aims at designing and evaluating network services using the architecture with the specific mobile data and use cases(e.g., IoT). On the other hand, the focus is to construct an unified architecture, which caters to the needs of various cellular systems to prompt cellular-Internet convergence. The goal is to prompt the architecture from experimental evaluations in the lab to trials with real users and applications [14].

Considering the situation of the aftermath of disaster where network resources and energy are scarce and the networks fragmented with only intermittent connectivity, GreenICN [20], a EU-JAPAN project, attempts to design a future Internet infrastructure emphasising on information-centric and looking beyond IP to efficiently distribute disaster notification and critical rescue information [21], and scalable and efficient video delivery based on pub/sub paradigm in both disaster and normal scenario.

div.head: A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T
div.p: CBMEN [22] of DARPA(Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency) seeks to design the network architecture and services to improve the efficient content distribution for applications in the tactical filed. SRI international provides an architecture support for the program, namely ENCODERS [23] or ICEMAN [24].

The widespread smart mobile terminals and prevalent social networks are accelerating the evolution of applications communicating mode of mobile Internet towards information-centric one. To satisfy the needs of applications, I-CAN project [25] is to develop a future wireless access architecture based on ICN integrating diverse access technologies, such as cellular networks and WiFi.

The current projects have revealed the benefits brought by information-focused operation mode, instead, little attention has been paid on the deployment incentives and specific migration paths from current Internet. Therefore, COMIT project [26] takes a closer look at the deployment challenges, which focuss primarily on preserving the current Internet infrastructure but makes full use of the advantages of information-centricity and location-independence.

Horizon 2020 [27], following the EU framework programme, becomes the biggest EU research and innovation programme with its emphasis on more innovation breakthroughs and world-class science discoveries. Horizon 2020 embraces almost all the current scientific projects in EU, some of which are relevant to ICN, that is, RIFE [28], UMOBILE [29], BONVOYAGE [30] and POINT [31].

It is believed that the basic access to the Internet is a fundamental human right [32]. However, it remains a great challenge to provide poor countries or regions with Internet access service. Fortunately, RIFE attempts to address challenges of providing affordable access to Internet combining the merits of ICN and DTN. More specifically, it harnesses unused transmission capacity and then utilizes the heterogeneous opportunities that range from local mesh and home networks to remote resources-scarce satellite networks so as to achieve affordable Internet access, combining with placing content and service approaching the edge [28].

As the complement of RIFE, UMOBILE targets the mobile part and extends Internet connectivity to rural areas, remote communities, nomadic districts and other areas lack of infrastructures. It develops an universal mobile-centric and opportunistic communications architecture, which also adopts the principles of DTN and ICN to enable opportunistic and more localized access to information through novel caching strategies at minimal resource exploitation [29].

In the sphere of IoT, one of the baseline scenarios selected for ICN by ICNRG, BONVOYAGE utilizes an innovative information-centric network to collect and distribute the heterogeneous, distributed and mobile data from data centers, sensors, vehicles, goods and people on the move [33]. The ultimate goal is to optimize multimodal transport platform for goods and passengers [30].

On the premise that many current IP applications are capable of performing "better" on an ICN network than on current Internet, POINT is to develop commercially viable "IP over ICN" deployment in terms of technologies and business value chains [34].

div.head: Trends
div.p: ICN proposed by academia has drawn the interest of a large number of researchers especially after the focus of the SIGCOMM, INFOCOM, MobiHoc and IEEE Communication Magazine and other international top conferences and journals. Although, the questions raised by Ghodsi et al. [35], Chai et al. [36] and Fayazbakhsh et al. [37] and the challenges in operation and deployment virtually extinguished the researchers' enthusiasm for ICN, it does not indicate that ICN would gradually phase out, quite to the contrary, the successive establishment of standards organization like ICNRG [38] and industry alliance like ENC [39] and NDN consortium [40] could further promote ICN from an academic concept to industrial deployment. Moverover, it was the first time that NDN has adopted in 2015 Networking and Communications Hype Cycle[41] by Gartner, the leading IT research and consulting firm. It suggests that NDN will most probably be employed by operators with maturity of its networking technology.

From the perspective of relevant projects, most of the projects at the first stage focused on theoretic issues on architecture, naming, routing, forwarding and security. While at the second stage, the overwhelming majority concentrated on specific application scenarios in order to promote self-improvement of architecture, such as Internet access, opportunistic communications, as well as multimodal transport. They also investigated the business models for ICN and the migration strategies of compatibility with TCP/IP, such as IP over ICN. The study on ICN, consequently, has been shifted from pure theory to specific application practice.

ICN taking content as the core of networking separates the content from the host, and thus reduces the requirement of host location-aware and enhances the mobility of terminals, which are necessary to ad hoc networking. Hence,

div.head: A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T
div.p: ICN is not only suitable for the future Internet but also for ad hoc and cellular mobile networking. And many projects involving wireless and mobile content-centric networking emerged at the second stage, such as GreenICN, RIFE and UMOBILE. The deployment scope of ICN is extended from fixed networks to dynamic networks.

div.head: Formation of ICMANET
div.p: Most of projects involving mobile networking appeared at the second stage, and meanwhile the project-driven funding spurs researchers' interest for examining the applicability of ICN principles to mobile networking. The following will specifically interpret its formation from the two aspects: the current challenges of ad hoc networking and the intrinsic applicability of ICN.

div.head: Challenges of ad hoc networking
div.p: The aim of ad hoc networking is to achieve data transmission between nodes. Due to the movement of nodes and dynamic changing of topology, however, for routing it generally requires to assume there is at least one complete end-to-end transmission path between two nodes at some time [42]. And then each node on the path is respectively in charge of forwarding data. In addition, it is particularly prone to turn into the intermittently connected network composed of several connected domains when the sparse nodes frequently moving. Then the source and destination node located in different connected domains must utilize the mode of "store-carry-forward" to achieve communications, which the networks are also referred as opportunistic networks(OppNet) [43] or delay tolerant networks(DTN) [44]. Many challenges the current ad hoc networking facing are to be introduced from physical conditions of ad hoc networks and shortcomings of HCN itself as follows.

First of all, ad hoc networking is highly vulnerable to packets loss or error in the wireless environment featuring signal interference, multipath fading and shadowing effect. Besides, in order to make the best use of broadcast nature of channel, it requires distributed channel access mechanism like CSMA/CA to avoid access violation. Simultaneously, it will lead to the control overhead and the issues including hidden terminal, exposed terminal, and throughput drop, etc. Furthermore, with the exception of vehicles, mobile nodes are limited to energy, computing and storage. To surmount these disadvantages, the appropriate networking protocols, therefore, are critical.

Subsequently, in spite of being an effective scheme in the fixed setting, TCP/IP is ill-suited for ad hoc networking according to the following reasons [45]. In the first place, there is no support of central infrastructure to assign IP addresses to nodes on the move, and IP address is not only the node's identifier but also the node's locator representing its topological locations. Once node moves out of the ad hoc setting, it will fail to be located and then IP addresses aggregation will not be feasible. Besides, the packets are meaningful to application layer but invisible to networking layer and then immediately deleted once passes one node, albeit they could be reused either for retransmission to the next hop or applications on other nodes. Moreover, with the high mobility of node, it suffers from great overheads to keep the binding between the node and its current address update. Hence, there is a fundamental tradeoff between accuracy of routing state and overhead to keep the state consistent. Furthermore, within the sender's wireless signal range, receivers generally are in better position than the sender to make forwarding decisions. The sender-driven transmission, however, fails to utilize the other receivers to take over the forwarding when the intended receiver may not be the expected of the sender any more.

div.head: Intrinsic applicability of ICN
div.p: It is the crucial requirement for ad hoc networking to support the moving of nodes. The following will shed light on the intrinsic applicability of ICN through mobility comparison between HCN and ICN in terms of interfaces usage, identification method, transport mechanism and content retrieval, as shown in Table 1.

HCN assumes that a specific network interface is bound to an address so that the upper applications can establish individual connections on different interfaces. But, it is hard to switch to other potential interfaces during the handoff. In contrast, it is not necessary to bind a specific data flow with an individual interface in ICN and different interfaces(such as WiFi, Bluetooth and 3/4G, etc.) can easily be multiplexed without application-aware.

HCN utilizes IP address to identify with a host but it is not easy to maintain its consistency in many mobile scenarios. The applications have to make them aware the moving nodes and keep their address update. Instead, ICN In-network cache employs unique name to identify with each content unit. Thus, it allows the applications to publish and consume content directly through its name without being aware of the network-layer address [46]. The greatest challenge to mobility in HCN is the dependency on sessions-based TCP. In order to acquire the up-to-date network states [47] for both two communications nodes, the node on the move requires the reestablishment of the session. While in ICN, the receiver-driven mode make session established for nodes less necessary.

div.head: A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T
div.p: Normally, content retrieval in HCN depends strongly on location concept in the content identifier(e.g., URL) [46]. As a result, any failure of the intermediate nodes on the path will make the content unavailable, particularly in mobile scenarios where paths can frequently fail owning to the network partitions [48]. On the contrary, ICN separates content from physical node to make the content reusable. Moreover, it is essential to perform in-network caching, which potentially accelerates content access by means of local caches retrieved before [47].

div.head: Overview of ICMANET
div.p: Owning to the intrinsic applicability of ICN, many efforts involving ICMANET have emerged recently, most of which attached a great importance to NDN. Comparing with the centralized architecture(such as DONA, NetInf and PURSUIT), the distributed NDN naturally fits ad hoc networking. In addition, the works [49], [50], [51], [52] and [53] are still dependent on TCP/IP, which requires establishing of the end-to-end connection and the hop-by-hop forwarding between communications nodes. Nevertheless, the overlay schemes fail to make the best of the broadcast nature of wireless channel and the benefits of in-network caching. Consequently, we will provide an overview of ICMANET in this section and only takes NDN based on the clean-slate design as the chief research object.

Table 2 shows the literature distribution of ICMANET, which involves the three scenarios(MANETs, VANETs and OppNet/DTN) and five topics(naming, routing, caching, transport and security). It was found that literatures evenly distributed among the scenarios but relatively concentrated at the topic of routing, which reflects the research hot topic of ICMANET. Obviously, as the key of ICN networking, routing is the hottest topic currently. Routing
div.formula: A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T
div.p: between the readability and wireless access technology can the naming scheme be designed to fit the requirements of application.

Secondly, NDN takes advantage of in-network caching on the nodes of transmission path to improve the availability of content, lower the redundant requests and decrease the retrieval latency. The current caching mainly concentrates at content placement and replacement. Once each node receives a piece of new content, the cache placement module will be responsible for deciding whether to cache or not. Thereafter, the node will replace a cached content according to the replacement strategy in case of the positive decision and the full storage space [11]. Leave a copy everywhere(LCE), the common strategy caching the new content in all intermediate nodes, is susceptible to cause cache redundancy and waste network resources. The current caching strategies proposed by [112], [113], [117], [114], [116], [97], [94], [107], [111] and [115] can be referred.

The hourglass-shaped architecture of NDN, moreover, introduces a strategy layer in charge of adaptive retransmission of Interest packet and adjustment of forwarding rate. Because of unreliable wireless channel, packets loss and error are likely to occur in the process of the packets transmission so that the Data packet may fail to be retrieved from the moving source node. For the reliable transmission, in case of failing to be satisfied with a corresponding Data in a given retransmission timeout(RTO) period, a new Interest requires to be resent by the requesting node. The RTO, although, is vital to recover the packet loss quickly and reduce the retransmission, the estimation of RTO for Interest is extremely hard especially for dynamic network. Amadeo et al. [70][121] and Wang et al. [91] proposed the respective calculation methods of RTO. In addition, in order to avoid congestion, each node takes charge of adjusting Interest forwarding rate according to some strategies such as that adopted by Yu et al. [118] and Amadeo et al. [70].

In addition, there are some security issues, such as cache pollution and denial of service attack, are still remained to be resolved notwithstanding the notable benefits of location-independent security. Furthermore, the constraint resources of the moving node and the lack of a trusted third-party in the wireless circumstance make it harder to secure content. So far, only the works [66], [123], [125] and [124] are relevant to the security.

The above only gives an overview of ICMANET in terms of naming, caching, transport and security since Amadeo et al. [10] have reviewed on the state-of-the-art of the information-centric wireless networking. The readers interested in further details, therefore, can refer to that literature. And, we will place particular emphasis on content routing of ICMANET in the following sections.

div.head: Conceptual model
div.p: At the network layer, HCN deliveries data in sender-driven(push) mode while ICMANET retrieves content in receiver-driven(pull). Owning to the essential difference, it is indispensable to define a conceptual model for content routing. The model defined in the paper, which is composed of receiver-driven mode, caching, node and content retrieval, can be demonstrated as a 4-tuple Receiver-driven Mode, Caching, Node, Content Retrieval . Without loss of generality, we will use the terms "sender"and "receiver" to indicate the transmission and reception in the context of single-hop, and employ "consumer" and "producer" to denote the communication nodes in the following sections.
• Receiver-driven Mode can be demonstrated as a 3-tuple Interest, Data, Match . There are two basic packets:
Interest packet and Data packet. A consumer sends Interest carrying the content name and then providers satisfy the request with corresponding Data in case of name matching [127].

• As discussed in Section 3, Caching can be illustrated as a 2-tuple Content Placement, Content Replacement . ICMANET adopts an independent unit "chunk" with the capacities of self-identity and self-certification. A node enables to adaptively adjust caching strategy to accelerate content retrieval according to the content attributes, node statuses and application requirements.

• Node can be demonstrated as a 3-tuple CS, PIT, FIB . CS is a temporarily storage space for incoming Data packets in order to accelerate reply to the same requests in the future. PIT is responsible for keeping the states of all the forwarded Interest packets that are not yet satisfied with a corresponding Data [128]. FIB is used to forward Interest through name-based lookup similar to the FIB in IP. • Content Retrieval, which takes charge of retrieving the complete content in the given Caching and Node, can be demonstrated as a 2-tuple Content Discovery, Content Delivery . As illustrated in Figure 3, Content Discovery refers to the process of using an Interest to discover the name-matched content and responds with a Data packet containing identifier or location information of content-hosted node, while Content Delivery refers to the process of utilizing the returned information to continue retrieving the rest of the content. We will categorize the current content routing from multiple dimensions. From the content discovery, it can be classified into the three categories: proactive, reactive and opportunistic routing. From the structure of network topology, it can be divided into flat routing and hierarchical routing. According to whether to utilize the GPS system, it can be divided into geo-assisted and non geo-assisted routing. For convenience, we will elaborate the routing schemes only from the dimension of content discovery, as illustrated in Figure 4.

div.head: A C C E P T E
Categorizing
div.p: To establish an optimal path for content delivery, it is required that the proactive routing advertise name prefixes or location information, which results in significant advertising overhead. By its receiver-driven nature, nonetheless, it needs additional mechanisms(e.g., new Interest control packet) to achieve proactive advertising, which also results in redundant overhead. Thus far, there are only a few studies relevant to the proactive routing.

The flooding or controlled flooding is utilized by reactive routing to discover content without the advertising. Moreover, opportunistic routing is able to reduce the overhead of advertising and flooding. Due to pulling content by a consumer, consequently, the receiver-driven ICMANET is consistent with the process of discovering content of the reactive and opportunistic routing. Therefore, most of current efforts on content routing mainly concentrate at the reactive and opportunistic routing. Besides, according to forwarding strategy, the reactive routing can be further subdivided into basic flooding, distance-aware, geo-aware and neighbor-aware, and meanwhile, opportunistic routing using the movement of nodes to disseminate content in the situation of intermittent connection can be further subdivided into agent-based, social-assisted and intelligence-assisted.

div.head: Overview
div.p: As shown in Table 3, we summarize and compare the current routing schemes in terms of type, whether to exploit GPS and hierarchical topology or not, content discovery, content delivery and application scenario, and elaborate the representatives in the following subsections.

div.head: Proactive
div.p: MobileCCN [58], one of the basic proactive scheme, in which provider floods the name prefixes and then any node can maintains their own FIB through periodically updating prefixes. Once receiving an Interest requested by a consumer, intermediate nodes will broadcast it to the neighbors until discovering the provider which has the matched content and a Data will return back according to the PIT. Obviously, the scheme is only suitable for sharing content in the small-scale and relatively stable ad hoc scenarios.

Yu et al. [79] pointed out it is required to design appropriate routing schemes according to the content type, therefore, the BFR, which uses a bloom filter(BF) to advertise the name prefixes is proposed for the popular content in typical urban VANET scenario. The topology spans a rectangular area recursively divided into several levels and thus the BF advertisements are propagated by cluster heads in the cluster hierarchy [79]. The content discovery mimics domain name resolution that moves up to the end destination cluster. In order to achieve mobility robustness in the high speed situation, HBFR [63][80] utilizes completely distributed BF aggregation without cluster heads being in charge of.

For each name component, SCALE [59][60], in which each node is assigned with a nodeID that indicates its geographic location, obtains a pair of two-dimensional coordinates through hash operation. A provider located at location X,Y advertises its name prefixes through Announce messages containing a tuple content name, nodeID, X,Y , which are either forwarded using geographic routing to the resolvers or simply flooded in the network when the content popularity is beyond a threshold. And then, a consumer sends an Interest packet including the pair name, closest pointer , where closest pointer is the pointer that is the Cartesian closest to the consumer among all the pointers related to the content [60]. The intermediate nodes forward the Interest based on the name or the pointer. SCALE, however, only fits for the small-scale settings(less than 200-300 nodes).

In the mobile scenarios, the Achilles heel of the proactive is huge advertising overhead even if only advertising name prefixes. The movement of provider, in addition, makes it more difficult to manage name prefixes. The low content delivery latency of the proactive routing can be easily amortized over the cost of maintaining routing states [129]. This kind of routing, therefore, is only suitable to be applied in small-scale scenarios with relatively stable topology.

div.head: A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T
A C C E P T E D M
div.p: A N U S C R I P T

div.head: Reactive
div.p: If there is no content routing plane to generate FIB in NDN, the forwarding strategy by default is a reactive scheme. Upon receiving an Interest, any node continues to flood and forward the returned Data along the reverse path similar to the reactive routing. But the underlying difference lies in that the reactive routing can use on-demand or controlled flooding to reduce the overhead caused by blind flooding.

div.head: Basic flooding
div.p: In [66], it applies the basic flooding, which is susceptible to cause redundant Interests and channel contention between adjacent nodes. Packet collision and loss, moreover, will be further deteriorated because of lack of RTS/CTS control mechanism in MAC layer. Therefore, this is the scheme that achieves a reliable transmission at the cost of redundant packets.

div.head: Distance-aware forwarding
div.p: LFBL [67][45] proposes a new distance table Distance Table (DT) similar to the IP routing table, in which mainly be used to store the distance information from node N to endpoint E. When a consumer is interested in some content, it floods an Interest including the distance between the consumer and the sender in the srcDist field to discover any available content, and meanwhile the other nodes can learn their distance to the consumer and keep their DT update. In order to response to the consumer, a Data packet containing the distance from the provider to the consumer in the dstDist field used to make forwarding decisions by intermediate nodes will be returned. Eventually, any node that overheard or forwarded the Interest is able to serve as forwarder for future requests without flooding any more. Once the DT populates, receivers will make forwarding decisions based on their DT and information in the received packet headers. As the blue nodes illustrated in Figure 5[67], a forwarder within the signal range of the sender, which is closer to the provider than the sender by comparing the distance in their DT to the dstDist, is qualified for forwarding. Without employing PIT and CS, however, LFBL fails to improve the availability of content and decrease the retrieval latency. It will cause redundant transmission even though the multipath forwarding can improve the reliability of content transmission.

div.head: Destination
div.p: Similarly, CHANET [68]

div.head: A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T
div.p: the successive chunks will be requested through broadcasting Int-Ack packets containing the selected identifier and distance representing the expected hops to the selected provider. Upon receiving the Int-Ack packets, any intermediate node compares its distance to consumer in CPT with hops in the packets, and forwards the packets and updates CPT in the event that the node is closer to consumer than the preferred provider.

Comparing with LFBL, the fundamental difference lies in that CHANET takes the advantages of the PRT, which can greatly reduce the forwarding hops of Data and the redundancy of Interest to the same content. E-CHANET [70] and CCVN [86][130]make adaptive improvements against the specific scenarios on the basis of CHANET. BREB [71], in addition, replenishes the routing recovery function which dynamically substitutes for the suboptimal one in case of failure of the optimal. The usage of PIT, indeed, can reduce the redundancy of Interest requests. And meanwhile, the fact that Data must forward reversely based on PIT also, however, results in the redundant Data packets. Hence, it is suggested that PIT be only applicable for scenarios without frequent topological changes.

div.head: Geo-aware
div.p: To achieve the energy-efficient Interest dissemination, Lu et al. [65] proposes a direction-selective forwarding scheme, in which forwarding decision is made by the sender, as shown in Figure 6 [65]. The sender divides its transmission space into four quadrants and broadcasts the Interest to all of the one-hop neighbors. Then, the receiver counts the duplicate Interest ever received before and sends an ACK packet including the duplicate count number back to the sender in case of no such content being available. After receiving the ACKs, the sender will select one node farthest to the sender and the duplicate count being equal to 1 in each quadrant as relay node, and then continue to broadcast CMD packet to one-hop neighbors attaching the selected relay identifer. The relay nodes perform the same round of the Interest forwarding, and the Data will be forwarded back to the consumer according to the path information carried by Interest once finding the content. Although Interests are only received and forwarded by few selective relay nodes, which can effectively reduce redundant packets, it will also reduce the possibility of discovering content. The sender at each hop, in addition, needs to interact with the neighbor nodes, which also increases the latency in retrieving content.
div.formula: A A A A Quadrant Ⅱ INT INT INT INT ACK ACK ACK ACK ACK ACK ACK CMD CMD CMD CMD (a) (b) (c) (d) Quadrant Ⅰ Quadrant Ⅳ Quadrant Ⅲ

div.head: A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T
div.p: Navigo [82] supporting the information distribution for any VANETs application exploits MGRS (Military Grid Reference System) to divide the real world into serval regions. After discovering the matched content by flooding, the provider attaches its geo-area name to the returned Data. The intermediate nodes along the the Data forwarding path will learn the binding between the name prefix and the corresponding geo-area [82], which provides guidance to forward the same content requests in the future to that geo-area only. For location-dependent application, a consumer can avoid Interest flooding by binding the name with the geo-area the consumer is interested in [82] and only forwards the Interest following the shortest path to the destination geo-area calculated before. Because the current NDN protocol fails to directly support the geo-area, however, the requirement of using the GeoFaces as agent to map from the name to the geo-area brings about the mapping overhead.

To reduce overhead of content discovery, LER [93] maintains the content location at each node. When two nodes encounter each other, they exchange their own content lists and locations known to them to update their local content locations [93]. Thereafter, if the name in Interest matches an entry in its list of content locations, it forwards the Interest attaching the destination location by geo-routing [94] instead of flooding. The scheme only targets an urban VANETs.

div.head: Neighbor-aware forwarding
div.p: Inspired by gossip protocol, BLOOGO [73] periodically exchanges beacon containing N b (x)(the neighborhood nodes in the transmission range of the sender) with other neighbors. Once an Interest including the neighbors set N b (s) of the sender s is sent, the receiver r will forward it only if N b (r) N b (s) . That means there is at least one neighbor node that does not covered by r. When there are multiple receiver nodes to be qualified for forwarding, MADN [74] uses the utility function D sr = |N b (r)/N b (s)| to select a receiver node in the coverage range of s. Albeit the state-less scheme is lightweight and power-efficient, it is susceptible to fail to forwarding owning to BF's false positive, and thus reduces the forwarding accuracy.

RUFS [89] enables each node to keep a list of Interest satisfied by itself, called Recent Satisfied List(RSL), and the list of Interest satisfied by its neighbors, called Neighbors Satisfied List(NSL). For each node, it is required to exchange its RSL with its neighbors periodically to keep the NSL update. The satisfaction time, current velocity, hops and Interest satisfaction rate in NSL are used to select the appropriate forwarder through a method of multi-criteria decision making. The periodic exchanges of RSL, however, will greatly waste network and bandwidth resources.

Overall, comparing with blind flooding for proactive advertising or reactive content discovery, the controlled flooding scheme can ensure the content routing accuracy under circumstances of the frequent topology changes and improve the routing scalability to some extent. Nonetheless, it will also suffer from the scalability issue particular in a large-scale ad hoc environments [65].

div.head: Opportunistic
div.p: In both proactive and reactive routing, there exists the active process of content discovery. Therefore, to avoid the overhead caused by the flooding and the routing failure caused by frequent topology changes, a passive discovery mechanism is required in the intermittent connected scenarios, which is called opportunistic routing. The mode of "store-carry-forward" is free to active flooding.

div.head: Agent-assisted
div.p: In the situation of intermittent connectivity and unpredictable duration of contact between nodes, for a consumer, it is not easy to directly contact provider. Therefore, Anastasiades et al. [95][96] [98] propose an agent-assisted content retrieval scheme, which delegates one-hop neighbor nodes as potential agents to retrieve the complete content according to temporal and spatial periodicity of mobility of the nodes [131]. Since the agents to be utilized for retrieving are more likely to discover the content, the scheme is capable of extending the content discovery scope and improving the content retrieval rate. The overhead of agent delegation, nevertheless, is only noticeable for small content [95].

Similarly, Wang et al. [54][91] employ data mule to periodically send Interest to retrieve content that could be potentially utilized by other nodes. The data mule continuously listen to the channel and cache the content it hears so as to respond to other nodes for the same request [54]. Due to the data mule acting as either temporary provider or relay node, it also enables to extend the scope of content discovery. But, the efficiency of the scheme not only depends on the content prefetch accuracy of data mule but also on the requirements of specific applications. For this point, Grassi et al. [55] [78][92] design V-NDN prototype supporting infrastructure and infrastructure-free networks on the basis of this

div.head: A C C E P T E D M
div.p: A N U S C R I P T scheme. To satisfy the requirements of the traffic information distribution in vehicular applications, the content name is linked to geolocation.

div.head: Social-assisted
div.p: Inspired by PeopleRank [132], SimBetTS [133] and BubbleRap [134] exploiting the social relationship between nodes to assist opportunistic data forwarding, Lu et al. [102][105] propose STCR, a social-tie based opportunistic content routing. Each node maintains a social-tie table containing the measure of social relationship between two nodes, which is utilized to compute centrality. Generally, the higher centrality node has more knowledge of the content [102]. Nodes will be divided into clusters though K-mean clustering algorithm. Accordingly, an Interest will be forwarded towards the most popular node in the centrality hierarchy to discover content. Once discovering the content provider, a social-tie hierarchy generated by the local social-tie table and K-mean clustering is used for content delivery.

Depending on the key idea behind random walk [135] is that high centrality nodes be likely to be visited by random walkers more often than average, Le et al. [108] propose SACR, in which each node is responsible for generating a random-walk probing packet every several seconds and counting in case of receiving a probing packet form the other. Generally, a node that has the higher value possesses the higher centrality. Both STCR and SACR are intra-community content routing, while STCRC [103] is inter-community routing. Nonetheless, the social-assisted scheme relies heavily on the portray of social relationship.

div.head: Intellegence-assisted
div.p: The idea of STIR [99] stems from ants' food retrieval behavior. As illustrated in Figure 7[99], it includes three mechanisms: Interest diffusion, Gradient management and Data diffusion [99]. The utility U(c, n) the scalar value for content c on node n is used to reflect temporal and spatial proximity between consumer and node, and then the collection of utilities for a given content c is defined as a gradient space from consumer to provider. Similar to the pheromone of ant colony optimization, the utility will be reinforcement and aging. The gradient field eventually is convergent and the shortest paths between consumer and provider is established. Consequently, the Data simply returns to the consumer along these paths. Similarly, Nguyen et al. [100][101]propose SIR, which is swarm intelligence scheme for content routing. Both STIR and SIR, however, suffer from slow convergence. In conclusion, opportunistic content routing can avoid the overhead of request flooding and proactive advertisement. But it's not suitable for time-sensitive application scenarios owning to the high transmission latency.

div.head: Dat a D a t a Interest Interest
Existing issues
div.p: In the last section, we elaborated the representative schemes and introduced their respective existing issues. Furthermore, we will summarize the general issues of content routing in this section.

div.head: Broadcasting
div.p: The broadcast nature of wireless channel can greatly contribute to multipath forwarding in NDN [91], but, there exists some challenges for broadcasting transmission, such as the broadcast packets redundancy and collisions and the network resources wastage, etc. [72] Therefore, it is necessary to address the broadcasting issues for improving the overall performance of content routing using flooding.

Moreover, it is inevitable to cause channel contention and packets collision in wireless medium, hence the appropriate collision avoidance mechanisms are required to counteract as shown in Table 4. Currently, the mechanisms adopted
div.formula: A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T
i j = |N b ( j)/N b (i)| Navigo
div.p: Listening period is inversely proportional to the distance between the sender and the neighbor BFR, HBFR Listening period is proportional to the distance between the node and the provider [87], [88] Listening period is proportional to the wireless transmission radius [64] Makes the timer for selective forwarders shorter than that of the others The basic idea of former is that a node defers forwarding a packet according to a timer while listening the channel and ultimately abort the transmission in event that it hears the same packet transmitted by other nodes, while the latter is that a node stops the transmission due to a counter used to recording the same packet copies received during the overhearing is beyond the pre-configured threshold. Apparently, the selection of the timer and the threshold is crucial to suppression effectiveness. While, acknowledgement mechanism exploits additional control packets to confirm whether the packet is received correctly or not. It can ensure the transmission reliability and robustness in ad hoc scenarios, however, the redundant control packets will cause the transmission overhead.

div.head: The others
div.p: Since the current studies on content routing is yet at an early stage of scheme design and simulation, it s lack of theoretical research, such as mathematical modeling or formal describing of content routing and further analysis of scheme performance, as well as efficiency assurance of QoS in dynamic scenarios [136]. In addition, the overwhelming majority of works on content routing only conduct simulations to verify and evaluate the feasibility of their schemes proposed respectively, and the unified emulator or testbed under real circumstances and evaluation criteria are still lacking.

Apart from the above mentioned, the following issues should be further studied. The issues in terms of Content Retrieval have been summarized when elaborated the schemes, and it will not be repeated here.

• For the Receiver-driven Mode, owning to the one-to-one correspondence of Interest and Data, it is vulnerable to channel contention between an Interest and the last returned Data and signal interference. To reduce the contention and interference caused by the receiver-driven paradigm, the management of Interest and Data requires to be considered.

• For the Caching, even though in-network cache can lower the redundant requests and decrease the retrieval latency, and meanwhile, the redundant copies may exacerbate the wastage of resources, such as energy, storage and link, etc, especially in mobile scenarios. Therefore, there is a fundamental tradeoff between the benefits of in-network cache and the cost of resources consumption. In addition, it is necessary to address the collaborative relationship between content routing and in-network cache under the resources-constrained conditions and resolve the cached fragment phenomenon [118].

• For the Node, to make full use of the limited space of node on the move, CS used to store content copies requires the efficient storage and index mechanism according to the content priority, arrival time and content size. Apart from CS, node needs to utilize PIT and FIB once receiving packet, hence, the efficient management, maintenance and search policy on entries of PIT and FIB are required.

div.head: Conclusion
div.p: Overall, the paper can be divided into two parts: ICMANET and the content routing. For the former, we firstly demonstrated the current advances in ICN and subsequently analyzed its development trends. Then, we explained the formation of ICMANET from the aspects of objective conditions of wireless environment, the disadvantages of the current TCP/IP networking and the intrinsic applicability of ICN. Finally, taking NDN based on the clean slate design as the chief research object, we sketched an overview of ICMANET in terms of naming, caching, transport and security. For the latter, at the very beginning, we defined a conceptual model for content routing composed of receiver-driven mode, caching, node and content retrieval. Besides, we categorized the content routing into the three types of proactive, reactive and opportunistic, and detailed the representative schemes. Finally, we summarized the current existing general issues of content routing. It is the first time the survey introduced the new cross-cutting area and provided the references and guidelines for readers approaching study on ICMANET and content routing.

div.p: We would like to express our heartfelt gratitude to professor Youping Li and the reviewers for their insightful suggestions. This work is supported by National High Technology Research and Development Program (863 Program) of China under Grant No. 2013AA013503, the National Science Foundation of China under Grants No. 61472080 and No. 61272532, the Consulting Project of Chinese Academy of Engineering under Grant No. 2015-XY-04, the Research Fund for the Doctoral Programme of Tianjin Normal University under Grant No. 52XB1504 and Collaborative Innovation Center of Novel Software Technology and Industrialization.
